headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Broadcom Inc.'s First Quarter Fiscal Year 2019 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Beatrice Russotto, Director of Investor
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Broadcom Inc.'s First Quarter Fiscal Year 2019 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Beatrice Russotto, Director of Investor Relations of Broadcom Inc. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tom Krause, Chief Financial Officer of Broadcom. After market close today, Broadcom distributed a press release and financial table describing our fin
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tom Krause, Chief Financial Officer of Broadcom. After market close today, Broadcom distributed a press release and financial table describing our financial performance for the first quarter of fiscal year 2019. If you did not receive a copy, you may obtain the information from the Investors section of Broadcom's website at broadcom.com.
This conference call is being webcast live, and a recording will be available via telephone playback for 1 week. It will also be archived in the Investors section of our website at broadcom.com.
During the prepared comments section of this call, Hock and Tom will be providing details of our first quarter fiscal year 2019 results, guidance for fiscal year 2019 and some commentary regarding the business environment. We will take questions after the end of our prepared comments.
Please refer to our press release today and our recent filings with the SEC for information on the specific risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements made on this call.
In addition to U.S. GAAP reporting, Broadcom reports certain financial measures on a non-GAAP basis. A reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the tables attached to today's press release. Comments made during today's call will primarily refer to our non-GAAP financial results. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Hock.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bea, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. So we had a good start to fiscal 2019, growing 9% in our first fiscal quarter compared to the same period a year ago. The strength of our business model delivered another quarter of sustaine
componenttext:
Thank you, Bea, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. 
So we had a good start to fiscal 2019, growing 9% in our first fiscal quarter compared to the same period a year ago. The strength of our business model delivered another quarter of sustained revenues, strong earnings and an extremely strong free cash flow. 
Our semiconductor business helped us relatively well. Not surprisingly, our wireless business was down sharply, and our storage business underperformed somewhat. However, these challenges were mitigated, more than mitigated by our networking business, which grew double digits year-over-year. In addition, we were very pleased to see that the broadband business has started to recover and stabilize in the quarter. In fact, putting in all together, the semiconductor segment was actually up year-over-year in the first quarter if you exclude the expected sharp decline in wireless.
Turning to infrastructure. This business, which includes SAN switching, mainframe and enterprise software delivered solid top line results, benefiting from a very robust enterprise spending environment. The integration of CA onto the Broadcom platform is very well underway, and we are confident that we can meet, if not exceed, in the long term -- exceed the long-term revenue and profitability target that we laid out for CA to you last year. In fact, renewals in our CA business have been strong this past quarter, and we believe we are -- the dollar commitments from our core customers will continue to grow. 
Many of our peers have commented that they are seeing a softening demand environment, especially out of China. While we're experiencing the same demand dynamics, we have factored in much of this macroeconomic backdrop when we provided fiscal 2019 guidance last quarter. As a result, after a solid start to the year, we are reaffirming our fiscal 2019 revenue guidance of $24.5 billion. Having said that, we expect our semiconductor business to bottom in the second fiscal quarter, driven almost entirely by the seasonal drop in wireless. But looking to the second half, we are confident the semiconductor business will resume very meaningful growth. This will be driven by strong product cycles in both wireless and networking, coupled with a recovery in broadband. Infrastructure software, on the other hand, is expected to sustain throughout the year. 
So in summary, our diversification strategy is working, and we are effectively managing the decline in wireless as well as in the broader semiconductor industry headwinds. 
Now let me turn over to Tom to provide you with more color in Q1.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hock. Consolidated net revenue for the first quarter was $5.8 billion, a 9% increase from a year ago. And EPS came in at $5.55, an 8% increase from a year ago, off of a 441 million weighted average fully diluted share count. In addition, fr
componenttext:
Thank you, Hock. 
Consolidated net revenue for the first quarter was $5.8 billion, a 9% increase from a year ago. And EPS came in at $5.55, an 8% increase from a year ago, off of a 441 million weighted average fully diluted share count. 
In addition, free cash flow is $2.03 billion or 35% of revenue. I would highlight free cash flow grew 39% year-over-year. 
The semiconductor solutions segment revenue was $4.4 billion and represented 76% of our total revenue this quarter. This was down 12% year-on-year on a comparable basis. But as Hock explained, the semiconductor segment was actually up slightly year-over-year in the first quarter, excluding wireless. 
Let me now turn to our infrastructure software segment. Revenue was $1.4 billion and represented 24% of revenue. SAN switching continues to perform extremely well. And as Hock mentioned, mainframe enterprise software is off to a good start.
Let me now provide additional detail on the financial performance. Operating expenses were $1.08 billion. Operating income from continuing operations was $3.05 billion and represented 52.7% of net revenue. 
Adjusted EBITDA was $3.24 billion and represented 55.9% of net revenue. This figure excludes $143 million of depreciation. 
Inventory decreased $50 million from the prior quarter. Similarly, semiconductor receivables were actually down, which is typical for Q1 even though receivables increased $352 million overall due to the CA acquisition. Total current liabilities excluding debt increased $2.5 billion due to CA. However, excluding CA, total current liabilities excluding debt decreased meaningfully more than receivables, primarily due to the payment of our annual performance bonus in Q1. 
In addition, we spent $99 million on capital expenditures. As a result, we had record Q1 free cash flow from operations at $2.03 billion or 35% of revenue. This represents 39% growth in free cash flow from operations compared to Q1 of 2018. 
I would note a couple of things. One, fiscal Q1 is typically our seasonally weakest cash flow quarter due to the annual performance bonus payment we make to our employees in the quarter that we accrue throughout the prior fiscal year. In Q1, we paid approximately $530 million in APV cash bonuses to our employees. 
And second, I would also note that we accrued $723 million of restructuring integration expenses, of which that includes $363 million of cash payments in the quarter. 
In Q1, we returned $4.6 billion to stockholders consisting of $1.1 billion in the form of cash dividends and $3.5 billion for the repurchase and elimination of 14.2 million AVGO shares. We ended the quarter with $5.1 billion of cash, $37.6 billion of total debt, 396 million outstanding shares and 451 million fully diluted shares outstanding.
Turning to our fiscal year 2019 guidance. As Hock discussed, we are reaffirming our full year revenue guidance of approximately $24.5 billion, including approximately $19.5 billion from semiconductor solutions and approximately $5 billion from infrastructure software. IP licensing is not expected to generate a material amount of revenue. 
On a non-GAAP basis, operating margins are expected to be approximately 51%. Net interest expense and others is expected to be approximately $1.25 billion. We do not contemplate any debt paydown in fiscal year 2019. 
The tax rate is forecasted to be approximately 11%. Depreciation is expected to be approximately $600 million. CapEx is expected to be approximately $550 million. And as a result, free cash flow from continuing operations is expected to be approximately $10 billion. 
And finally, stock-based compensation expense is expected to be approximately $2 billion. As we outlined last quarter, we granted approximately 31 million of restricted and performance stock units as part of the multiyear grant that would vest over the next 7 years. As a result, for modeling purposes, we would expect the fully diluted share count in the second quarter to be approximately 450 million. This excludes any stock repurchases. Similarly, for modeling purposes, we would expect stock-based compensation expense to be approximately $530 million in Q2. Looking forward beyond Q2, we would expect the share count excluding the stock repurchases and eliminations to remain relatively unchanged, and the quarterly stock-based compensation in the second half of 2018 will start to decrease slightly each quarter. We would expect stock-based compensation to level out at approximately $1.5 billion in 2021. 
Now on the capital allocation. Our capital allocation strategy remains the same. We plan to maintain the current quarterly dividend payout of $2.65 per share throughout the year, subject to quarterly board approval, which means we plan to pay out over $4 billion in cash dividends in fiscal 2019. In addition, we remain committed to buying back and eliminating a total of $8 billion of stock in fiscal 2019.
That concludes my prepared remarks. [Operator Instructions] Operator, please open up the call for questions.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Harlan Sur with JP Morgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Harlan Sur with JP Morgan.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on the solid quarterly execution. Hock, on the strong double-digit year-over-year momentum and computer acceleration segment, you've been shipping your new Tomahawk 3 switching platform now since the second half of last year. I think Googl
componenttext: Congratulations on the solid quarterly execution. Hock, on the strong double-digit year-over-year momentum and computer acceleration segment, you've been shipping your new Tomahawk 3 switching platform now since the second half of last year. I think Google is using a [indiscernible] 200 gig. Amazon is going to transition to 400. We're hearing good things from Baidu, Tencent and all of the cloud guys. Additionally, you're ramping computer acceleration ASICs into some of the big cloud guys as well. The question is do you anticipate continued to double-digit year-over-year growth for the full year here for the networking business as the pipeline here appears fairly strong?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Very good question, Harlan. And now that listening to you, you really got me going, yes, in networking. And it's broader in data centers, but let's start with data centers. Tomahawk 3, which is the 12.8 terabit top of the rack switch, which has just barel
componenttext: Very good question, Harlan. And now that listening to you, you really got me going, yes, in networking. And it's broader in data centers, but let's start with data centers. Tomahawk 3, which is the 12.8 terabit top of the rack switch, which has just barely started production shipments. In fact, we do expect -- we are fully expecting the ramp of Tomahawk 3 as part of the broader data center scale-out with 400 gig pipes in the connect, so to speak, to really start just about right now. In fact, our Q2, fiscal Q2 and progressing up to the rest, the end of the year as more and more on the names you were mentioning type of cloud jumping and expand upgrade as the same data centers and simply because, as you know, expanding the capacity of data centers and pipes is the simplest way to be decongest, to minimize or mitigate congestion control in these huge data centers, in this large cloud. So there's a broad refreshing and upgrading of data centers among these cloud guys. One area, as mentioned, Tomahawk 3 are shipping, which is just starting this quarter in significant volumes. What's also not so perhaps obvious but is very real for us is the fact that [indiscernible] 400 gigabit per second throughput pipes, you need interconnect, fiber optic interconnect that are built and dedicated in that area. And it's very high-tech products, which we are very deeply engaged in. And that brings the content in bio multiple sectors in this data center And then as you expand the top of the right switch, I you have you need to connect data center to data center, what is called DCI interconnectivity. And the approach that is being taken, which we are also very engaged in, have been multiple OEMs supporting the cloud guys is obviously coherent, coherent fiber optic connection at 400 gig. And we believe we are very much in the lead on that area as well. So these are product lines -- product cycles we are seeing that are continuing their emphasis of double-digit growth in networking. And it expands more than that. In routing, we are going to be launching and ramping our new generation router, Jericho 2, probably in Q3 of our fiscal year. And that's going into edge routing, call routing among the service providers, especially the telecom guys. And we're starting to see the preparation in that happening. So yes, we feel very good about about networking and the ability to sustain the level of growth we have been seeing.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Seymour with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Seymour with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sticking on the formally called wired category, Hock, you mentioned that -- I think you said the broadband space has stabilized and recovered. Can you talk a little bit about the product cycles that are driving demand in that segment? And any geographic c
componenttext: Sticking on the formally called wired category, Hock, you mentioned that -- I think you said the broadband space has stabilized and recovered. Can you talk a little bit about the product cycles that are driving demand in that segment? And any geographic color, product cycle color would be helpful.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sure, Ross. Yes, in broadband, happy to say, finally, the things recovered. And a big part of this driving the recovery is cable motors, with the delivery DOCSIS, as they call it, 3.1. We've seen implementations across multiple carriers, service pro
componenttext: Sure. Sure, Ross. Yes, in broadband, happy to say, finally, the things recovered. And a big part of this driving the recovery is cable motors, with the delivery DOCSIS, as they call it, 3.1. We've seen implementations across multiple carriers, service providers of DOCSIS 3.1 so that's very good. What we're also seeing, of course, is in gateway access, which is a big part of broadband. Among many carriers, too, is the new generation of DSL, digital subscriber line, as they need to expand capacity and throughput and go through what called the next-generation 35B and we see a lot of that in Europe, some in North American carriers. But what's also equally interesting is as they go to the last mile into households, what we're also seeing is adoption of wireless connectivity or what we all call WiFi. And what we're seeing now is as we see this wired gateways, whether it's cable, modem DOCSIS 3.1 of digital subscriber line, we are seeing -- especially in the back half of the year, enterprises and more and more service providers, telecoms start to attach the next-generation WiFi, WiFi 6 on to those gateways. And in WiFi 6, I'm very, very pleased to note that we are very much in the lead in having developed and productized a whole suite of products that address towards those enterprise, and so this provides us and -- but most of that will be only shipping, we believe, in the second half of the year, but fiscal and both calendar. And we're looking forward to seeing that happen, but it's very nice product cycle that will continue -- that will basically push the recovery of our broadband business.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

And we're hearing that there may be double ordering ahead of some possible sanctions. So I'm kind of wondering how you think about that and how you handicap that for the full year guidance.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: I probably know as much as you do, seriously, in terms of what's available, publicly available and what's the concerns and the issues overhanging broadly, Chinese exporter, China and the specific high-tech companies like Huawei from China. They are good c
componenttext: I probably know as much as you do, seriously, in terms of what's available, publicly available and what's the concerns and the issues overhanging broadly, Chinese exporter, China and the specific high-tech companies like Huawei from China. They are good customers, and they buy products, which obviously helps their products competitive in the global export market. And I hope they continue to do so, but certainly, the overhang of that is something that we are closely monitoring and are very concerned about. But as far as specific things you're mentioning, I'm not able to basically comment on it simply because I don't know.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Actually, a quick clarification on a question. I believe, Hock, I believe you mentioned software could sustain throughout the year. That suggests annualized closer to $6 billion rather than the $5 billion I think you had before. And if that is the case, s
componenttext: Actually, a quick clarification on a question. I believe, Hock, I believe you mentioned software could sustain throughout the year. That suggests annualized closer to $6 billion rather than the $5 billion I think you had before. And if that is the case, shouldn't profit margins be higher than what you had? And then the question that has been some consolidation in semis and but I'm just curious how you think if at all there is an impact on Broadcom. And even if there isn't, how you just think about the M&A environment in semis.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: You have 2 questions here. Very clever. Let me try to -- let me start with the second one. It's easy. I mean, as I say, we have done quite a bit of acquisitions in very strong assets -- there's an echo -- in the semiconductor space. And obviously, it's so
componenttext: You have 2 questions here. Very clever. Let me try to -- let me start with the second one. It's easy. I mean, as I say, we have done quite a bit of acquisitions in very strong assets -- there's an echo -- in the semiconductor space. And obviously, it's something we continue to look at because, obviously, semiconductor is a core area for us and -- but you also know we're not necessarily limiting ourselves to that. We look to a broader area of technology, software and appliances as Brocade would be considered. And while we continue the interest in the semiconductor space and there's still targets and be continue to be very thoughtful and timely in terms of the time -- in terms of how we approach those acquisitions. And we have observed our behavior over the last several years. We tend to do it in a very -- in a measured pace simply because it's important. In fact, it's critical on any acquisition to make that we can integrate it very, very well. And that's what we're doing with CA right now, and we're right in the thick of it, as you noticed in the numbers we're going through as we drive down to generate the kind of business model we expect to get out of CA. Turning on to the next question you asked, which is -- which leads to software, yes, it's turning out to be a very, very nice deal for us. We actually are seeing for our core customers, as you recall, we have differentiated customers associated with the very core large customers who consumes both mainframe and enterprise distributor software as opposed to much smaller long tail of noncore customers. If you look at those core customers we're focusing on, after about at least 1 quarter now today more than 1 quarter of going through selling, renewals and adoption of our software, we feel that the business model has been extremely -- our business model has been extremely successful. I mean, the growth as we see of dollars that we get through renewals and expansion of footprint in those core customers are -- it's pretty -- it's surpassing our expectations. It's gone double digits. But that's only 3 months, so we're still early stage, and we'll continue to push that. But as we also made certain announcements on at least 1 or maybe 2 deals we have done on our new PLA model of both mainframe and enterprise free software, this has been very well received in the marketplace by our core customers, and we are hopeful it's something that makes so much sense that we'll expand -- we'll expect to see more and more of these significant transactions occurring as we move forward through the rest of the year.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Pitzer with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Pitzer with Credit Suisse.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'll echo my congratulations on the results. Hock, relative to the full year guide, it does imply like many of your semi peers some pretty meaningfully above seasonal growth half on half in the semi solutions business. And I think you did a good job on so
componenttext: I'll echo my congratulations on the results. Hock, relative to the full year guide, it does imply like many of your semi peers some pretty meaningfully above seasonal growth half on half in the semi solutions business. And I think you did a good job on some of the prior questions specific data center and broadband access of some of the bottoms-up product cycles that are driving that. I'd be curious or it would be helpful if I could get your views and wireless and how that progresses throughout the year and how you should -- how you're thinking or how we should be thinking about your content this year versus dependency on units in this year within the wireless.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Somehow I knew this was going to come up somehow, Sure enough, you did. Yes, I know. It's actually not that because that product cycle in wireless is, in all our views, very predictable. And we will see that happen in our Q3 -- fiscal Q3, Q4 of this -- of
componenttext: Somehow I knew this was going to come up somehow, Sure enough, you did. Yes, I know. It's actually not that because that product cycle in wireless is, in all our views, very predictable. And we will see that happen in our Q3 -- fiscal Q3, Q4 of this -- of this fiscal '19. It will. We're already starting production in our wafer sets, which has longer product cycle on and some of the products. And we will see, for want of better word, because it's seasonal and it's very significant sharp bounce back, which adds to my -- our confidence that our full year guidance is something that's going to happen. Very simple. And that in the second half, we'd see that meaningful, you correctly pointed out, somewhat double-digit growth in the semiconductor segment of our business. It's -- as I mentioned in answer to earlier questions, data center, especially networking, we have a whole slew of new product cycles. We'll generate a big part of that double-digit growth. So in our view, wireless -- actually, that happened in the past. And in this particular year, perhaps the difference between this coming year '19 versus '18 is simply 2 things. One is we're probably going to get better share as mentioned before. And secondly, content increase. It always happens, year after year, as I mentioned an example, in WiFi, you'll see WiFi 6. WiFi 6 is not just in enterprise and gateways in service providers. We are seeing WiFi 6, the new generation in 20082.11 AA and in handsets, that drives -- I call it strong content increase and as they increase amount of bands in that we constantly see as basically wireless continue to proliferate in various areas in the world, continues to expand the amount of bands, content in this next-generation phone. So all that is going to drive a bounce back with perhaps increased content for -- for our products. As far as volume is concerned, yes, like I will probably be as uncertain as you are how much the volume would be but regardless, it's -- there's a lot of mitigating factors, and the biggest part of it is pure content increase.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: So understanding the confidence on the semi ramp, your guidance also implies the infrastructure software business has to decelerate pretty materially as you go through the earnings. It seems like right now in Q1, the CA business must have already been hit
componenttext: So understanding the confidence on the semi ramp, your guidance also implies the infrastructure software business has to decelerate pretty materially as you go through the earnings. It seems like right now in Q1, the CA business must have already been hitting pretty close to the $3.5 billion kind of annualized run rate that you were talking about that was a few years out. So I guess, like, what drove the strength of CA in Q1 and why does that business decelerate, have to decelerate so markedly as we go through the rest of the year in order to fit into the guidance that you've provided?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: It's Tom. I think one element is we don't want to get between the details between CA and SAN switching, but we're taking a conservative approach. It's just the first quarter out of the gate, got 3 quarters to go. As mentioned, we are actually pretty surpr
componenttext: It's Tom. I think one element is we don't want to get between the details between CA and SAN switching, but we're taking a conservative approach. It's just the first quarter out of the gate, got 3 quarters to go. As mentioned, we are actually pretty surprised with the number of ELA and PLA opportunities that we see in the pipeline. And a lot of our success in terms of growing the dollars is going to be driven by our building to convert those into wins. But so far so good. I think we're going to take this one quarter at a time at the moment for now given that are only one quarter into the year we feel very comfortable reaffirming the guidance and of course we feel comfortable with the operating profit as well as the cash flow expectations going forward.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

componenttext: But you said CA would sustain during the rest of the year. So does that mean that Brocade has to come down a lot more or just overall conservatism?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

componenttext: So what we said the infrastructure software segment continue to sustain throughout the year. That's our expectation, but we are taking on a conservative approach relative to the overall outlook for the business.

componenttext: But if it sustains, wouldn't you be a 5.6 for the year instead of 5?

componenttext: Our next question comes from Toshi Hari with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: I had some questions on 5G as it relates to your wireless business. Based on preliminary discussions with your customers, what sort of content uplift are you expecting in your wireless business as 5G is inserted going forward? And from a timing perspectiv
componenttext: I had some questions on 5G as it relates to your wireless business. Based on preliminary discussions with your customers, what sort of content uplift are you expecting in your wireless business as 5G is inserted going forward? And from a timing perspective, do you think -- is it more of a 2020 dynamic when 5G starts to move the needle? Or is it 2020 and beyond?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: It's very good interesting question, and you're asking areas are very vast uncertainty here. But my sense of it is you start to see a little bit of it in 2020, but it will be only a small part. I think it's 5G actually the impacts content in components in
componenttext: It's very good interesting question, and you're asking areas are very vast uncertainty here. But my sense of it is you start to see a little bit of it in 2020, but it will be only a small part. I think it's 5G actually the impacts content in components in handsets, high-end smartphones, will only really impact in the big way, I think, beyond 2020. 2020, we'll see some start, but the attach rate, for lack of better word to use, is going to be not that high. But you're right. Beyond 2020, as 5G comes in, and you probably heard and seen that the amount of content especially for on RF and FBAR and here in this case, as those FBAR content attaches itself more and more to antenna and various other parts of the phone, will be quite significant but not so in 2020.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

componenttext: Our next question comes from Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just question for Tom and the back of the strong gross margin outside in the quarter, can you talk about just trends you're seeing in gross margin for the core semiconductor business? And then software, just how we think about expectations through the yea
componenttext: Just question for Tom and the back of the strong gross margin outside in the quarter, can you talk about just trends you're seeing in gross margin for the core semiconductor business? And then software, just how we think about expectations through the year?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig. You can see that gross margins are exceptional. They're all over 70% in the quarter. A lot of that is driven by including CA in the business. But you're right, the business continues to increase from a gross margin perspective. Mix helps. As
componenttext: Sure, Craig. You can see that gross margins are exceptional. They're all over 70% in the quarter. A lot of that is driven by including CA in the business. But you're right, the business continues to increase from a gross margin perspective. Mix helps. As wireless comes down, we benefit, as I think you know, from the rest of the portfolio in semis being at or above the corporate average. But looking out longer term, we talked about this a lot. We continue to see the opportunity to improve gross margins, which directly translates, of course, into our operating margins and our free cash flow conversion so you can see that continue.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Harsh Kumar with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Harsh Kumar with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: First of all, congratulations. Exceptional execution. I wanted to follow up on the gross margin question, maybe for Tom. They stepped up quite dramatically. In one of the field trips, I think you had mentioned that it really an acquisition about a year to
componenttext: First of all, congratulations. Exceptional execution. I wanted to follow up on the gross margin question, maybe for Tom. They stepped up quite dramatically. In one of the field trips, I think you had mentioned that it really an acquisition about a year to hum and really produce results. So question is did you capture the vast majority of CA benefits really quickly in 1Q? Or is the best from CA sort of reserved for the back half and later on?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I think as you might be able to sort of look through the numbers, we're still not fully optimized around CA. We're only one quarter in. So you've seen some meaningful improvement in profitability for the company that it includes CA. But when y
componenttext: No. I mean, I think as you might be able to sort of look through the numbers, we're still not fully optimized around CA. We're only one quarter in. So you've seen some meaningful improvement in profitability for the company that it includes CA. But when you look specifically at gross margins, it's a number of elements within the CA business tie gross margins, primarily services as well as support. So we've taken some actions to improve gross margins and improve the P&L, in general, one in particular as we announced the deal with HCl and have outsourced a lot of our service activity to going forward, for the CA business. But as we continue to work through our model, which is really driving these PLAs talked about, we see the opportunity to continue to get better returns of our investment which includes improving our gross margins going forward. So we would expect them to continue to improve, not just this year but really over the long term.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: If I could add to that, on CA, we continue to go through transitions. And you're right. It takes at least a year for us to so call hum. In the case of software companies, I believe it will take longer because these are contractual commitments, probably cl
componenttext: If I could add to that, on CA, we continue to go through transitions. And you're right. It takes at least a year for us to so call hum. In the case of software companies, I believe it will take longer because these are contractual commitments, probably closer to 2 years, but it will get there. But the biggest the big part other than combining software and hardware now and CA in the software -- infrastructure software side still transitioning its improvement. It's just one quarter. We expect to see more reductions. And these are not just cost of goods sold but down below the line of operating expenses [indiscernible] One for Q1 is very critical to is the fact that this product mix. Wireless is down and the other products are humming along, semiconductor products. And remember, year by year nature of product life cycles in semiconductor products, we always have an opportunity to expand by delivering more value to our customers, expand our gross margin around 50 to 100 basis points on just its natural cadence. That mix, I think, is adding a lot of tailwind through improvement in gross margin.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'd like to maybe touch back on wireless. This rebound you're going to see in the second half of the year, I understand you've got a year-over-year issue here just kind of [indiscernible] last year, but this is flattening out units. It sous like there's g
componenttext: I'd like to maybe touch back on wireless. This rebound you're going to see in the second half of the year, I understand you've got a year-over-year issue here just kind of [indiscernible] last year, but this is flattening out units. It sous like there's going to be a much stronger rebound than normal on content alone. Correct me if I'm wrong, but you've got areas playing with just enhances alone of course your standard ball business, which covers I think, about 2.4 gig more products in the congestion area now isn't getting much more acute in the next year especially as 5G comes on. But the WiFi it's 11 AX like you mentioned not the enterprise but receiving enhances isn't this the case that you got a big lead over your closest competitor, maybe Qualcomm here. So should we expect, one, to see a big rebound content; two, for maybe just have more legs than we'd otherwise expected next year? I know units are an issue, but given WiFi itself is being deployed and you play stronger to that, it should last longer, shouldn't it?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your comments, but I want to be played down very straight down the center simply. We'd see a rebound. My view is a normal rebound, and it's a normal rebound. And while content increases, it's not really over the top that -- by that much either. But those
componenttext: Your comments, but I want to be played down very straight down the center simply. We'd see a rebound. My view is a normal rebound, and it's a normal rebound. And while content increases, it's not really over the top that -- by that much either. But those who get comparing against last year, it's relatively an easier compare. So we do see -- we definitely see a rebound, and this will be a good rebound, but it's not -- it will not be an extraordinary rebound. Just want to emphasize that. Just your normal rebound. It's not hard to compare year-on-year against last year versus second half fiscal '19 the fact that, that will be an improvement.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

componenttext: Our next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Wells Fargo.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: A lot of questions on wired and wireless has been asked, but I wanted to ask about the storage business. The storage business, I think you mentioned, was up. I don't know how much in this quarter, but I'm curious and kind of similar what kind of things ar
componenttext: A lot of questions on wired and wireless has been asked, but I wanted to ask about the storage business. The storage business, I think you mentioned, was up. I don't know how much in this quarter, but I'm curious and kind of similar what kind of things are we to be focused on in that piece of the business over the next couple of quarters? And how do you assume that and that can go through the course of this year?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, very good interesting question. In storage, we have a mixed bag here. A bag -- a lot of it, not all of it, but a lot of it relates to hard disk drive. And as you know this has nothing to and we see that no different from the others Our mitigating fa
componenttext: Well, very good interesting question. In storage, we have a mixed bag here. A bag -- a lot of it, not all of it, but a lot of it relates to hard disk drive. And as you know this has nothing to and we see that no different from the others Our mitigating factors here is that most of our hard disk drives, in fact, all our hard disk drive component sales goes to nearline or basically data centers. We don't do -- we do relatively less in PC, desktops or mobile. So we do see the impact of it being weak but not as extreme as obviously the industry is saying. So that helps mitigate it, but that's not the growth area. Where we see a hopefully embedded new product cycle coming in is the fact that storage is -- especially on Flash, SSDs, PCI Express. Second half of the year, we see pushing a strong push in the marketplace on PCI Express and we see a lot of interesting opportunities related to that, be it in storage or even also in amounts in offload computing and from viewpoint of machine learning, GPU to GPU connectivity, but it's also related to storage and that is what's quite interesting in storage over the next -- over the next -- well, actually over the rest of this year, especially the second half. All right?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Hock, if you cut through the end markets and look instead at the business on a geographic basis, I'm well aware that when you shift to one region, there may not be consumption in that region that China's big export economy certainly, but can you talk to t
componenttext: Hock, if you cut through the end markets and look instead at the business on a geographic basis, I'm well aware that when you shift to one region, there may not be consumption in that region that China's big export economy certainly, but can you talk to the pace of demand that you're seeing in China as best you can tell it, in particular relative to inventories there?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Good question. No surprise. Across the regions, as far as I can sense, China is the weakest. We all see that. We all know that. And I'm talking domestic demand products and our partnership to the -- ship to those regions, used in that region indigenously.
componenttext: Good question. No surprise. Across the regions, as far as I can sense, China is the weakest. We all see that. We all know that. And I'm talking domestic demand products and our partnership to the -- ship to those regions, used in that region indigenously. And it's the weakest region. It also has collateral impact we see to some extent on certain sectors in Japan and certain sectors in Europe, less so in the U.S. But broadly, so China has an impact beyond just the region in South China. It also impacts a couple of other regions but North America continues to be quite decent, and that's what helps us mitigate this overall macroeconomic saturation.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Broadcom Inc.'s First Quarter Fiscal Year 2019 Financial Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Beatrice Russotto, Director of Invest
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Broadcom Inc.'s First Quarter Fiscal Year 2019 Financial Results Conference Call. 
At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Beatrice Russotto, Director of Investor Relations of Broadcom Inc. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tom Krause, Chief Financial Officer of Broadcom. After the market closed today, Broadcom distributed a press release and financial table describing
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Hock Tan, President and CEO; and Tom Krause, Chief Financial Officer of Broadcom. 
After the market closed today, Broadcom distributed a press release and financial table describing our financial performance for the first quarter of fiscal year 2019. If you did not receive a copy, you may obtain the information from the Investors section of Broadcom's website at broadcom.com.
This conference call is being webcast live, and a recording will be available via telephone playback for 1 week. It will also be archived in the Investors section of our website at broadcom.com.
During the prepared comments section of this call, Hock and Tom will be providing details of our first quarter fiscal year 2019 results, guidance for fiscal year 2019, and commentary regarding the business environment. We will take questions after the end of our prepared comments.
Please refer to our press release today and our recent filings with the SEC for information on the specific risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements made on this call.
In addition to U.S. GAAP reporting, Broadcom reports certain financial measures on a non-GAAP basis. A reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the tables attached to today's press release. Comments made during today's call will primarily refer to our non-GAAP financial results. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Hock.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bea, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. So we had a good start to fiscal 2019, growing 9% in our first fiscal quarter compared to the same period a year ago. The strength of our business model delivered another quarter of sustaine
componenttext:
Thank you, Bea, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. 
So we had a good start to fiscal 2019, growing 9% in our first fiscal quarter compared to the same period a year ago. The strength of our business model delivered another quarter of sustained revenues, strong earnings and an extremely strong free cash flow. 
Our semiconductor business held up relatively well. Not surprisingly, our wireless business was down sharply, and our storage business underperformed somewhat. However, these challenges were mitigated, more than mitigated by our networking business, which grew double digits year-over-year. In addition, we were very pleased to see that the broadband business has started to recover and stabilize in the quarter. In fact, putting in all together, the semiconductor segment was actually up year-over-year in the first quarter if you exclude the expected sharp decline in wireless.
Turning to infrastructure. This business, which includes SAN switching, mainframe and enterprise software delivered solid top line results, benefiting from a very robust enterprise spending environment. The integration of CA onto the Broadcom platform is very well underway, and we are confident that we can meet, if not exceed, in the long term -- exceed the long-term revenue and profitability target that we laid out for CA to you last year. In fact, renewals in our CA business have been strong this past quarter, and we believe we are -- the dollar commitments from our core customers will continue to grow. 
Many of our peers have commented that they are seeing a softening demand environment, especially out of China. While we're experiencing the same demand dynamics, we have factored in much of this macroeconomic backdrop when we provided fiscal 2019 guidance last quarter. As a result, after a solid start to the year, we are reaffirming our fiscal 2019 revenue guidance of $24.5 billion. 
Having said that, we expect our semiconductor business to bottom in the second fiscal quarter, driven almost entirely by the seasonal drop in wireless. But looking to the second half, we are confident the semiconductor business will resume very meaningful growth. This will be driven by strong product cycles in both wireless and networking, coupled with a recovery in broadband. Infrastructure software, on the other hand, is expected to sustain throughout the year. 
So in summary, our diversification strategy is working, and we are effectively managing the decline in wireless as well as the broader semiconductor industry headwinds. 
Now let me turn over to Tom to provide you with more color on Q1.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hock. Consolidated net revenue for the first quarter was $5.8 billion, a 9% increase from a year ago. And EPS came in at $5.55, an 8% increase from a year ago, off of a 441 million weighted average fully diluted share count. In addition, free
componenttext:
Thank you, Hock. Consolidated net revenue for the first quarter was $5.8 billion, a 9% increase from a year ago. And EPS came in at $5.55, an 8% increase from a year ago, off of a 441 million weighted average fully diluted share count. 
In addition, free cash flow is $2.03 billion or 35% of revenue. I would highlight free cash flow grew 39% year-over-year. 
The semiconductor solutions segment revenue was $4.4 billion and represented 76% of our total revenue this quarter. This was down 12% year-on-year on a comparable basis. But as Hock explained, the semiconductor segment was actually up slightly year-over-year in the first quarter, excluding wireless. 
Let me now turn to our infrastructure software segment. Revenue was $1.4 billion and represented 24% of revenue. SAN switching continues to perform extremely well. And as Hock mentioned, mainframe enterprise software is off to a good start.
Let me now provide additional detail on our financial performance. Operating expenses were $1.08 billion. Operating income from continuing operations was $3.05 billion and represented 52.7% of net revenue. 
Adjusted EBITDA was $3.24 billion and represented 55.9% of net revenue. This figure excludes $143 million of depreciation. 
Inventory decreased $50 million from the prior quarter. Similarly, semiconductor receivables were actually down, which is typical for Q1 even though receivables increased $352 million overall due to the CA acquisition. Total current liabilities, excluding debt, increased $2.5 billion due to CA. However, excluding CA, total current liabilities excluding debt decreased meaningfully more than receivables, primarily due to the payment of our annual performance bonus in Q1. 
In addition, we spent $99 million on capital expenditures. As a result, we had record Q1 free cash flow from operations at $2.03 billion or 35% of revenue. This represents 39% growth in free cash flow from operations compared to Q1 of 2018. 
I would note a couple of things. One, fiscal Q1 is typically our seasonally weakest cash flow quarter due to the annual performance bonus payment we make to our employees in the quarter that we accrue all throughout the prior fiscal year. In Q1, we paid approximately $530 million in APV cash bonuses to our employees. 
And second, I would also note that we accrued $723 million of restructuring integration expenses, of which that includes $363 million of cash payments in the quarter. 
In Q1, we returned $4.6 billion to stockholders consisting of $1.1 billion in the form of cash dividends and $3.5 billion for the repurchase and elimination of 14.2 million AVGO shares. We ended the quarter with $5.1 billion of cash, $37.6 billion of total debt, 396 million outstanding shares and 451 million fully diluted shares outstanding.
Turning to our fiscal year 2019 guidance. As Hock discussed, we are reaffirming our full year revenue guidance of approximately $24.5 billion, including approximately $19.5 billion from semiconductor solutions and approximately $5 billion from infrastructure software. IP licensing is not expected to generate a material amount of revenue. 
On a non-GAAP basis, operating margins are expected to be approximately 51%. Net interest expense and others expected to be approximately $1.25 billion. We do not contemplate any debt paydown in fiscal year 2019. 
The tax rate is forecasted to be approximately 11%. Depreciation is expected to be approximately $600 million. CapEx is expected to be approximately $550 million. And as a result, free cash flow from continuing operations is expected to be approximately $10 billion. 
And finally, stock-based compensation expense is expected to be approximately $2 billion. As we outlined last quarter, we granted approximately 31 million of restricted and performance stock units as part of the multiyear grant that will vest over the next 7 years. As a result, for modeling purposes, we would expect the fully diluted share count in the second quarter to be approximately 450 million. This excludes any stock repurchases. 
Similarly, for modeling purposes, we would expect stock-based compensation expense to be approximately $530 million in Q2. Looking forward beyond Q2, we would expect the share count, excluding any stock repurchases and eliminations, to remain relatively unchanged, and the quarterly stock-based compensation in the second half of 2019 to start to decrease slightly each quarter. We would expect stock-based compensation to level out at approximately $1.5 billion in 2021. 
Now on to capital allocation. Our capital allocation strategy remains the same. We plan to maintain the current quarterly dividend payout of $2.65 per share throughout the year, subject to quarterly board approval, which means we plan to pay out over $4 billion in cash dividends in fiscal 2019. In addition, we remain committed to buying back and eliminating a total of $8 billion of stock in fiscal 2019.
That concludes my prepared remarks. [Operator Instructions] Operator, please open up the call for questions.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Harlan Sur with JP Morgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Harlan Sur with JP Morgan.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Hock, on the strong double-digit year-over-year momentum in your data center network team and computer acceleration segment. You've been shipping your new Tomahawk 3 switching platform now since the second half of last year. I think Google is using it for
componenttext: Hock, on the strong double-digit year-over-year momentum in your data center network team and computer acceleration segment. You've been shipping your new Tomahawk 3 switching platform now since the second half of last year. I think Google is using it for 200 gig. We hear Amazon is going to transition to 400. We're hearing good things from Baidu, Tencent and all of the cloud guys. Additionally, you're ramping compute acceleration ASICs into some of the big cloud guys as well. The question is, do you anticipate continued double-digits year-over-year growth for the full years here? For the networking business as the pipeline here appears fairly strong?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Very good question, Harlan. And now that listening to you, you really got me going, yes, in networking. And it's broader than just data centers. But let's start with data centers. Tomahawk 3, which is the 12.8 terabit top of the rack switch, has just bare
componenttext: Very good question, Harlan. And now that listening to you, you really got me going, yes, in networking. And it's broader than just data centers. But let's start with data centers. Tomahawk 3, which is the 12.8 terabit top of the rack switch, has just barely started production shipments. In fact, we do expect -- we are fully expecting the ramp of Tomahawk 3 as part of the broader data center scale-out with 400 gig pipes in the connect, so to speak, to really start just about right now. In fact, our Q2, fiscal Q2 and progressing up to the rest of the end of the year as more and more on the names you were mentioning type of cloud jumping and expand -- and upgrade as the same as data centers, and simply because, as you know, expanding the capacity of data centers and pipes is the simplest way to decongest, to minimize or mitigate congestion control in these huge data centers, in this large cloud tech. So there's a broad refreshing and upgrading of data centers among these cloud guys. One area, as mentioned, Tomahawk 3, are shipping, which is just starting this quarter in significant volumes. What's also not so perhaps obvious, but is very real for us, is the fact that not at the run 400 gigabit per second throughput pipes, you need interconnect, fiber optic interconnect that are built and dedicated in that area. That's very high-tech products, which we are very deeply engaged in. And that brings the content on bio multiple sector in this data center realm. And then as you expand the top of the right switch, I can't resist saying, you have to -- you need to connect data center to data center, what is called DCI interconnectivity. And the approach that is being taken, which we are also very engaged in, have been multiple OEMs, who are supporting the cloud guys, is obviously coherent, coherent fiber optic connection at 400 gig. And we believe we are very much in the lead on that area as well. So these are product lives of product cycles we are seeing that are continuing their impetus of double-digit growth in networking. And it expands more than that. In routing, we are going to be launching and ramping our new generation router, Jericho 2, probably in Q3 of our fiscal year. And that's going into Edge routing, call routing, among the service providers, especially the telecom guys. And we're starting to see the preparation in that happening. So yes, we feel very good about networking and the ability to sustain the level of growth we have been seeing.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sticking on the formally called wired category, Hock, you mentioned that the -- I think you said the broadband space had stabilized and recovered. Can you talk a little bit about the product cycles that will be driving demand in that segment? And any geog
componenttext: Sticking on the formally called wired category, Hock, you mentioned that the -- I think you said the broadband space had stabilized and recovered. Can you talk a little bit about the product cycles that will be driving demand in that segment? And any geographic color, product cycle color would be helpful.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sure. Ross. Yes. In broadband, happy to say, finally, the thing recovered. And a big part of driving the recovery is cable modem with their delivery DOCSIS, as they call it, 3.1. We've seen implementations across multiple carriers, service providers
componenttext: Sure. Sure. Ross. Yes. In broadband, happy to say, finally, the thing recovered. And a big part of driving the recovery is cable modem with their delivery DOCSIS, as they call it, 3.1. We've seen implementations across multiple carriers, service providers of DOCSIS 3.1 so that's very good. What we're also seeing, of course, is in gateway access, which is a big part of broadband. Among many carriers, too, is the new generation of DSL, digital subscriber line, as they need to expand capacity and throughput and go through -- what they're calling the next-generation G.fast or 35B and we're seeing a lot of that in Europe, some in North American carriers. So but what's also equally interesting is as they go to the last mile into households, what we're also seeing is adoption of wireless connectivity or what we all call Wi-Fi. And what we're seeing now is as we see this wired gateways, whether it's cable modem, DOCSIS 3.1, our digital subscriber line, we are seeing -- especially in the back half of the year, enterprises and more, and more service providers, telecoms start to attach the next-generation Wi-Fi, Wi-Fi 6 on to those gateways. And in Wi-Fi 6, I'm very, very pleased to note that we are very much in the lead in having developed and productized a whole suite of products that perfectly address towards those enterprise, and so this provides us -- and that -- but most of that will be only shipping, we believe, in the second half of the year, but fiscal and both calendar. And we're looking forward to seeing that happen, but it's a very nice product cycle that will continue -- that will basically push the recovery of our broadband business.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

componenttext: Hock, I'm wondering how you handicap Huawei and I believe that they're a kind of a mid-single-digit customer right now. And we're hearing a lot of evidence that they may be double ordering ahead of some possible sanctions. So I'm kind of wondering how you think about that and how you handicap that for the full year guidance.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: I probably know as much as you do, seriously, in terms of what's available, publicly available, and what's -- and the concerns and the issues overhanging, broadly, Chinese exporter, China, and the specific high-tech companies like Huawei from China. They
componenttext: I probably know as much as you do, seriously, in terms of what's available, publicly available, and what's -- and the concerns and the issues overhanging, broadly, Chinese exporter, China, and the specific high-tech companies like Huawei from China. They are good customers, and they buy products, which obviously, helps their products be competitive in the global export market. And I hope they continue to do so. But certainly, the overhang of that is something that we are closely monitoring and are very concerned about. But as far as specific things you're mentioning, I'm not able to basically comment on it simply because I don't know.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Actually, a quick clarification and a question. I believe, Hock, you mentioned software could sustain throughout the year. That suggests annualized closer to $6 billion rather than the $5 billion I think you had before. And if that is the case, shouldn't
componenttext: Actually, a quick clarification and a question. I believe, Hock, you mentioned software could sustain throughout the year. That suggests annualized closer to $6 billion rather than the $5 billion I think you had before. And if that is the case, shouldn't profit margins be higher than what you had? And then, the question, Hock, that has been some more consolidation in semis NVIDIA acquiring Mellanox. But I was curious how you think if at all there is an impact on Broadcom? And even if there isn't, how you just think about the M&A environment in semis.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. You have 2 questions here. Very clever. Let me try to answer -- let me start with the second one. It's easy. I mean, as I say, we have done quite a bit of acquisitions in very strong assets -- there's an echo -- in the semiconductor space. And it's
componenttext: Okay. You have 2 questions here. Very clever. Let me try to answer -- let me start with the second one. It's easy. I mean, as I say, we have done quite a bit of acquisitions in very strong assets -- there's an echo -- in the semiconductor space. And it's obviously in here. It's something we continue to look at because, obviously, semiconductor is a core area for us and -- but you also know we're not necessarily limiting ourselves to that. We look towards a broader area of technology, software and appliances as Brocade would be considered. And while we continue the interest in the semiconductor space and there are still targets, and we'll be -- continue to be very thoughtful and timely in terms of the time -- in terms of how we approach those acquisitions. And we have observed our behavior over the last several years. We tend to do it in a very -- on a measured pace simply because it's important. In fact, it's critical on any acquisition we make that we can integrate it very, very well. And that's what we're doing with CA right now, and we're right in the thick of it, as you noticed in the numbers we are going through as we drive down to generate the kind of business model we expect to get out of CA. Turning on to the next question you asked, which is -- which leads to software. Yes, it's turning out to be a very, very nice deal for us. We actually are seeing for our core customers, as you recall, we have differentiated customers associated between very core large customers who consumes both mainframe and enterprise distributed software as opposed to much smaller long tail of non-core customers. If you look at those core customers we are focusing on, after about at least one quarter now today more than one quarter of going through selling, renewals and adoption of our software, we feel that the business model has been extremely -- our business model has been extremely successful. I mean, the growth as we see of dollars that we get through renewals and expansion of use footprint in those core customers are -- it's pretty -- it's surpassing our expectations. It's gone double digits. But that's only 3 months, so we're still early stage, and we'll continue to push that. But as we have also made certain announcements on at least 1 or maybe 2 deals we have done on our new PLA model of both mainframe and enterprise breed software, this has been very well received in the marketplace by our core customers, and we are hopeful it's something that makes so much sense that we'll expand -- we'll expect to see more and more of these significant transactions occurring as we move forward through the rest of the year.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019

componenttext: Our next question comes from John Pitzer with Credit Suisse.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Hock, relative to the full year guide, it does imply like many of your semi peers -- some pretty meaningfully above seasonal growth half on half in the semi solutions business. And I think you did a good job on some of the prior questions specific to data
componenttext: Hock, relative to the full year guide, it does imply like many of your semi peers -- some pretty meaningfully above seasonal growth half on half in the semi solutions business. And I think you did a good job on some of the prior questions specific to data center and broadband access of some of the bottoms-up product cycle that are driving that. I'd be curious or it would be helpful if I could get your sort of views on wireless and how that progresses throughout the year and how you should -- how you're thinking or how we should be thinking about your content this year versus dependency on units this year within the wireless.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Somehow I knew this was going to come up somehow, some ways. Sure enough, you did. Yes, I know. It's actually not that because that product cycle in wireless is, in all our views, as is mine, very predictable. And we will see that happen in our Q3 -- fisc
componenttext: Somehow I knew this was going to come up somehow, some ways. Sure enough, you did. Yes, I know. It's actually not that because that product cycle in wireless is, in all our views, as is mine, very predictable. And we will see that happen in our Q3 -- fiscal Q3, Q4 of this -- of this fiscal '19. It will. We're already starting production in our wafer sets, which has longer product cycle on FBARs in some of the products. And we will see, for want of better word, because it's so seasonal and it's very significant, a sharp bounce back, which adds to my -- our confidence that our full year guidance is something that's going to happen. Very simple. And that in the second half, we'd see that meaningful, you correctly pointed out, somewhat double-digit growth in the semiconductor segment of the business. It's -- as I mentioned in answer to earlier questions, data center, especially networking, we have a whole slew of new product cycles. We'll generate a big part of that double-digit growth. So in our view, wireless -- actually, that's happened in the past. And in this particular year, perhaps the difference between this coming year '19 versus '18 is simply 2 things. One is we're probably going to get better share as mentioned before. And secondly, content increase. It always happens, year after year, as I mentioned an example, in Wi-Fi, you'll see Wi-Fi 6. Wi-Fi 6 is not just in enterprise and excess gateways in service providers. We are seeing Wi-Fi 6, the new generation in 802.11ax in handsets, and that drives -- I call it strong content increase, as the increase amount of bands in the ad bar that we constantly see as basically wireless continue to proliferate in various areas of the world, continues to expand the amount of bands, content in this next-generation phone. So all that is going to drive a bounce back with perhaps increased content for -- for our products. As far as volume is concerned, yes, like you, I will probably be as uncertain as you are, how much the volume would be? But regardless, it's -- there's a lot of mitigating factors, and the biggest part of it is pure content increase.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: So understanding the confidence on the semi ramp, your guidance also implies the infrastructure software business has to decelerate pretty materially as we go through the year. It know it seems like right now in Q1, the CA business must have already been
componenttext: So understanding the confidence on the semi ramp, your guidance also implies the infrastructure software business has to decelerate pretty materially as we go through the year. It know it seems like right now in Q1, the CA business must have already been hitting pretty close to the $3.5 billion kind of annualized run rate that you were talking about that was a few years out. So I guess, like, what drove the strength of CA in Q1? And why does that business decelerate, have to decelerate so markedly as we go through the rest of the year in order to fit into the guidance that you've provided?

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: Stacy, it's Tom. I think one element is we don't want to get into the details between CA and SAN switching, but we're taking a conservative approach. It's just the first quarter out of the gate. We've got 3 quarters to go. As Hock mentioned, we are, actua
componenttext: Stacy, it's Tom. I think one element is we don't want to get into the details between CA and SAN switching, but we're taking a conservative approach. It's just the first quarter out of the gate. We've got 3 quarters to go. As Hock mentioned, we are, actually, pretty pleasantly surprised with the number of ELA and PLA opportunities that we see in the pipeline. And a lot of our success in terms of growing the dollars of each of these accounts is going to be driven by our ability to convert those into wins. But so far so good. So I think we're going to take this one quarter at a time. But for now, given that we're only one quarter into the year, we feel very comfortable reaffirming guidance on the topline. And of course, we feel comfortable with the operating profit as well as the cash flow expectations going forward.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: But you said CA would sustain through the rest of the year. So does that mean that Brocade has to, like, come down a lot? Or is it just like overall conservatism that's in the number.
componenttext: But you said CA would sustain through the rest of the year. So does that mean that Brocade has to, like, come down a lot? Or is it just like overall conservatism that's in the number.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: No. Stacy, what we said is that the software, the infrastructure software segment would continue to sustain throughout the year. That's our expectation, but we are taking a conservative approach relative to the overall outlook for the business.
componenttext: No. Stacy, what we said is that the software, the infrastructure software segment would continue to sustain throughout the year. That's our expectation, but we are taking a conservative approach relative to the overall outlook for the business.

headline: Broadcom Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Mar 14, 2019
componenttextpreview: But if it sustains, wouldn't you be at 5.6 for the year instead of 5?
componenttext: But if it sustains, wouldn't you be at 5.6 for the year instead of 5?
